Class AlignText

  • java.lang.Object
    • AlignText

  • public class AlignText
extends java.lang.Object
    This AlignText program is used to take a source text file, wrap the words in it to lines specified by a maximum character length, and then align the text to a specified alignment. The output is the final formatted text.
    Since:
    30/09/2017
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    pmh20 (Haubrick PM)

    • Constructor Detail

        public AlignText()

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        The main method carries out the main flow of the program. It changes the setup based on the arguments it is given, and calls the methods, which carry out the detailed work.
        Parameters:
        args - - This is an array of strings. This must either take 2 parameters (for the 'Basic' assignment), or 3 parameters (for the 'Enhancements' of the assignment). -args[0] - This parameter must be the exact path to the text file desired to be formatted. -args[1] - This parameter must be an integer that represents the max desired character length per line. -args[2] - This parameter is optional, and takes the form of a single capital letter to specify the desired alignment type. Use 'L' for left, 'R' for right, 'C' for centre, and 'J' for justify.
        See Also:
        FileUtil.readFile(String)

      • isValidInt

        public static boolean isValidInt(java.lang.String lineLength)
        This method is used to handle the exception if anything but a valid integer is given as a parameter.
        Parameters:
        lineLength - - This is the args[1] given to main, and should be the line length.
        Returns:
        a boolean, stating whether the supplied parameter is an integer or not.

      • printError

        public static void printError(int errorType)
        This method is invoked whenever certain errors occur, and prints the respective error message to the screen.
        Parameters:
        errorType - - This is to distinguish between the error messages that the assignment spec requires.

      • wrapText

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> wrapText(int wrappingNumber,
                                                        java.lang.String[] oldArray,
                                                        java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> lastLineTracker)
        This method does the most important job of the program, which is to split the text up into the correct number of words for a line (determined by the specified line length of characters) for ALL CASE SCENARIOS. Some parts may look over-complicated, but have been implemented as safety features that allow the code to scale to (for example): (a) When the max character line length is smaller that the first word. (b) When the max character line length is larger than the paragraph length.
        Parameters:
        wrappingNumber - - This is the line length (in characters) that the line must not exceed (bar special cases, such as (a) above.
        oldArray - - This is the array that contains the entire text, each paragraph stored in its own String element.
        lastLineTracker - - This is an ArrayList that stores index values which indicate where the last line of each paragraph is stored in the new ArrayList that is created to store the output line Strings.
        Returns:
        the reference to the ArrayList created for storing Strings of the output lines.

      • rightAlign

        public static void rightAlign(java.util.List<java.lang.String> output,
                              int wrappingNumber)
        This method is invoked either when the "R" argument is given to main, or when none is supplied (all 'Basic' tests). It aligns the text by adding a number of white-spaces, and prints the result to the screen (returning nothing).
        Parameters:
        output - - This is the ArrayList containing all the output lines (wrapped correctly) in their respective Strings.
        wrappingNumber - - This is the line length (in characters) that the line must not exceed (bar special cases).

      • leftAlign

        public static void leftAlign(java.util.List<java.lang.String> output)
        This method is invoked either when the "L" argument is given to main('Enhancement' tests). It is very simple, as text is automatically left aligned when printed. The result is printed to the screen.
        Parameters:
        output - - This is the ArrayList containing all the output lines (wrapped correctly) in their respective Strings.

      • centreAlign

        public static void centreAlign(java.util.List<java.lang.String> output,
                               float wrappingNumber)
        This method is invoked either when the "C" argument is given to main('Enhancement' tests). It aligns the text by adding a number of white-spaces (half that of the right alignment), and prints the result to the screen (returning nothing).
        Parameters:
        output - - This is the ArrayList containing all the output lines (wrapped correctly) in their respective Strings.
        wrappingNumber - - This is the line length (in characters) that the line must not exceed (bar special cases).

      • justifyAlign

        public static void justifyAlign(java.util.List<java.lang.String> output,
                                java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> lastLineIndex,
                                int wrappingNumber)
        This method is invoked either when the "J" argument is given to main('Enhancement' tests). It aligns the text by spreading the additional white-spaces evenly between the words to produce lines that align with both the left and right edges, with evenly spaced words. It then prints the result to the screen (returning nothing).
        Parameters:
        output - - This is the ArrayList containing all the output lines (wrapped correctly) in their respective Strings.
        lastLineIndex - - This is an ArrayList that stores index values which indicate where the last line of each paragraph is stored in the new ArrayList that is created to store the output line Strings.
        wrappingNumber - - This is the line length (in characters) that the line must not exceed (bar special cases).
